title: Mitigating Bias in RAG: Controlling the Embedder
author: Taeyoun Kim (Carnegie Mellon University), Jacob Mitchell Springer (Carnegie Mellon University), Aditi Raghunathan (Carnegie Mellon University), Maarten Sap (Carnegie Mellon University), ...
relevance_why: The study introduces methods to mitigate bias in retrieval augmented generation systems, which could be applied to enhance fairness in audio-data generation tasks.
field: Social and Economic Aspects of ML-Fairness
background: Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) systems use a language model, an embedder, and a corpus to generate outputs, which can lead to biased results if any component has inherent biases.
contribution: This paper introduces techniques for controlling the bias of the embedder to mitigate overall system bias in RAG, achieving a more balanced output.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods of debiasing focused predominantly on LLMs and corpus adjustments, often losing utility in generative performance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work emphasizes adjusting only the embedder's bias, showing that it can effectively control the overall bias of RAG systems without significant loss in utility.

key_innovation: Unique focus on reversing the bias in a compact embedder, demonstrating that this approach can overcome biases in larger LLMs.
real_world_impact: Improving bias mitigation in AI systems can enhance the fairness of generated outputs in various applications, from content creation to automated decision-making.
limitations: No extensive discussion of potential overfitting issues in the embedder was mentioned.

new_terms.RAG: **Retrieval-augmented generation** refers to AI systems that integrate a retrieval mechanism with language generation to enhance the factual accuracy and diversity of outputs.
new_terms.embedder: **Embedder** is a component that retrieves relevant documents from a corpus based on a given query, which influences the overall bias of the generated output.

open_sourcing: The authors have made datasets and code available at https://github.com/danielkty/debiasing-rag
